title: AB 2687
content: The people of California enact the following. Section 23152 of the Vehicle Code in California prohibits driving under the influence of alcohol. It is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or higher. The BAC limit is based on grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. If a chemical test shows a BAC of 0.08% or higher within three hours of driving, it is presumed that the person was over the limit while driving. (c) It is illegal for a person addicted to drugs to drive. This does not apply to those in an approved narcotic treatment program. (d) It is illegal to drive a commercial vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood. If a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.04% or more alcohol, it is presumed the person was over the limit while driving. (e) Starting July 1, 2018, it is illegal to drive with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood when a passenger for hire is in the vehicle. A passenger for hire is someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. In a prosecution, it is assumed the person was over the limit if a chemical test within three hours after driving shows 0.04% or more alcohol. (f) It is also illegal to drive under the influence of any drug. It is unlawful to drive under the influence of any drug or the combined influence of alcohol and drugs. Additionally, it is illegal to drive with a blood alcohol concentration of 0.08% or more, which causes bodily injury to another person. In a prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.08% or more alcohol in their blood while driving if a chemical test within three hours confirms the same. Neglecting any duty while driving does not require proof of violating specific sections of the law. In a prosecution, it is presumed that a person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving a commercial motor vehicle if a chemical test within three hours confirms the same. Neglecting any duty while driving does not require proof of violating specific sections of the law. It is illegal to drive a motor vehicle with 0.04% or more alcohol in the blood if a passenger for hire is in the vehicle and causes bodily injury to another person. Passenger for hire refers to someone who pays or is expected to pay for the ride. In a prosecution, it is assumed the person had 0.04% alcohol if confirmed by a test within three hours. In a prosecution, it is assumed that a person had 0.04% or more alcohol in their blood while driving a vehicle if confirmed by a test within three hours. It is illegal to drive under the influence of drugs or a combination of alcohol and drugs, leading to bodily injury to someone other than the driver. No reimbursement is required by this act as it creates a new crime or infraction, eliminates a crime or infraction, or changes penalties, within the meaning of the Government Code and California Constitution.
